snippet: A program using new technology and flexible pricing based on supply and demand appears to have made finding a parking space easier in parts of San Francisco.
abstract: San Francisco is trying to shorten the hunt for parking with an ambitious experiment that aims to make sure that there is always at least one empty spot available on every block that has meters; the program, which uses new technology and the law of supply and demand, raises the price of parking on the city’s most crowded blocks and lowers it on its emptiest blocks.

byline.original: By MICHAEL COOPER and JO CRAVEN McGINTY
byline.contributor: Michael Cooper reported from San Francisco, and Jo Craven McGinty from New York. Malia Wollan contributed reporting from San Francisco.

lead_paragraph: A program using new technology and flexible pricing based on supply and demand appears to have made finding a parking space easier in parts of San Francisco.

headline.seo: Program Aims to Make the Streets of San Francisco Easier to Park On
headline.main: A Meter So Expensive, It Creates Parking Spots
headline.print_headline: A Meter So Expensive, It Creates Parking Spots
